notes.note:
Starting with Firefox 127, we're enabling a new anti-tracking feature in Nightly: [Bounce Tracking Protection][1]. This protection detects bounce trackers based on redirect behavior and periodically purges their cookies & site data to prevent tracking.


  [1]: https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/M6erM0SjPTM

Starting with [Firefox for Android][1] 128, the new tab strip feature for tablets is available for testing in Nightly builds! This enhancement makes tab management more intuitive and efficient, providing a smoother browsing experience for devices in that form factor. Please share your feedback on Google Play and/or the [Mozilla Connect post][2] to help us improve it further.


  [1]: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.mozilla.fenix
  [2]: https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/tablet-amp-mobile-ui-tab-bar-for-android/idi-p/333
Starting with Firefox 128, hovering the mouse over an unfocused tab will now display a visual preview of its contents in Nightly builds.
Added support for multiple languages in the same document spoken in macOS VoiceOver.
Starting with Firefox 129, Firefox Nightly blocks third-party cookie access with Enhanced Tracking Protection's Strict mode and also in Private Browsing.

Starting with Firefox 129, Firefox Nightly will automatically try to use a secure HTTPS connection whenever possible when loading a page. This behavior is known as "HTTPS-First", or "HTTPS Upgrades", and has been the default in Firefox's private browsing mode since Firefox 91. [Here][1] is a blog post from when this feature was introduced in Private Browsing.


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2021/08/10/firefox-91-introduces-https-by-default-in-private-browsing/
Starting with Firefox 129, location search is available in the weather widget on the new tab page in Firefox Nightly. Users can select their desired location to view the current weather conditions.

Reader View has an enhanced Text and layout menu with new options for character spacing, word spacing, and text alignment. These changes offer users a more accessible reading experience.

Reader View now has a Theme menu with additional Contrast and Gray options. You can also select your own custom colors for text, background, and links from the Custom tab.

[Address Autofill][1] enabled for users in France and Germany.


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatically-fill-your-address-web-forms
HTTPS is replacing HTTP as the default protocol in the address bar on non-local sites. In case a site is not available via HTTPS, Firefox will fall back to HTTP.

Starting with Firefox 126, the [shape()][1] function on [clip-path][2] property is now supported in nightly builds.


  [1]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#shape-function
  [2]: https://drafts.fxtf.org/css-masking-1/#the-clip-path

Starting with Firefox 126, the [shape()][1] function on [offset-path][2] property is supported in nightly builds.


  [1]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#shape-function
  [2]: https://drafts.fxtf.org/motion-1/#offset-path-property

Starting with Firefox 126,  [interpolation][1] between [path()][2] function and [shape()][3] function is now supported in nightly builds.


  [1]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#interpolating-shape
  [2]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-1/#funcdef-basic-shape-path
  [3]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#funcdef-shape

Starting with Firefox 127, the [relative color syntax][1] is supported in CSS color functions in Nightly builds. This allows to create colors based on other colors.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_colors/Relative_colors

Starting with Firefox 128, Firefox Nightly now has initial support for the [CHIPS (Cookies Having Independent Partitioned State)][1] standard.


  [1]: https://github.com/privacycg/CHIPS

Added support for querying the [encryption key system][1] config in [mediaCapabilities.decodingInfo()][2] API.


  [1]: https://w3c.github.io/media-capabilities/#mediacapabilitieskeysystemconfiguration
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/MediaCapabilities/decodingInfo

Added support for [Float16Array][1] typed arrays along with new [DataView][2] methods for reading and setting Float16 values, and a `Math.f16round(`) static method that can be used to round numbers to 16 bits. The new type is useful for sharing data with a GPU, in particular for use cases where it makes sense to trade off precision for memory consumption.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Float16Array
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/DataView

Added support for [@starting-style][1]. This `at-rule` allows to define styles that are applied to an element when it is first rendered, enabling transitions on elements that are added to the DOM or that have their display type changed from none to another value.

  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/@starting-style

Added support for the [transition-behavior][1] CSS property. This property allows us to create a transition on discrete animated CSS properties.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/transition-behavior

## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 10 or later

### Recommended Hardware
-  1 gigahertz (GHz) or faster compatible processor or System on a Chip (SoC)
-  1GB of RAM / 2GB of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  500MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.15 or later

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 or Apple silicon processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - glibc 2.17 or higher
    - GTK+ 3.14 or higher
    - libglib 2.42 or higher
    - libstdc++ 4.8.1 or higher
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - PulseAudio

Firefox Nightly gets updated every day and as a consequence, the release notes for the Nightly channel are updated continuously to reflect features that have reached sufficient maturity to benefit from community feedback and bug reports. 

**Warning: Features listed here may or may *not* make a final release of Firefox.**

In addition to these release notes, you can follow ongoing development on our [@FirefoxNightly][1] X account as well as read our [Nightly Blog][2].

You can interact with other Firefox Nightly users and give your feedback to Mozilla staff in the [Nightly Matrix room][3] on chat.mozilla.org.


  [1]: https://x.com/FirefoxNightly
  [2]: https://blog.nightly.mozilla.org
  [3]: https://chat.mozilla.org/?#/room/#nightly:mozilla.org
